instruction: How did the researchers evaluate the performance of the LCTF-based hyperspectral imaging system in vegetated areas?
Output: The researchers evaluated the performance of the LCTF-based hyperspectral imaging system in vegetated areas by conducting a field campaign in the Philippines. During this campaign, UAV-based hyperspectral imaging was performed in several vegetated areas, and the spectral reflectances of 14 different ground objects were measured. The obtained dataset was then used for calibration and validation of the LCTF-based hyperspectral imaging system. Additionally, the researchers applied a machine learning approach using a support vector machine (SVM) model to the dataset and produced a high-resolution classification map from the aerial hyperspectral images. The classification accuracy in vegetated areas was found to be 94.5%.

instruction: How did the researchers overcome the limitations of conventional UAV-based multi spectral imaging systems to evaluate the performance of the LCTF-based hyperspectral imaging system in vegetated areas?
Output: The researchers overcame the limitations of conventional UAV-based multi spectral imaging systems by adopting a liquid crystal tunable filter (LCTF). The LCTF allowed them to transmit selected wavelengths without the need to exchange optical filters. This enabled them to overcome the limited number of sensors mountable on a UAV and select the optimal combination of spectral bands for their hyperspectral imaging system.
